cell.p:
This Company's system of submarine telegraph
cables is the most direct and quickest means of
communication from Egypt to Europe, North and
South America, East, South and West Africa,
India, Australia, New Zealand, China and Japan.

To secure quick transmission, telegrams should
be marked Via Eastern.

For latest average time to London, see daily
bulletin in this paper.

STATIONS IN EGYPT: Alexandria, Cairo,
Suez, Port-Tewfik, Port-Saïd, Suakin. Head
Office. London.

Le réseau de cables télégraphiques sous-marins de cette compagnie constitue le moyen de communication le plus direct et le plus rapide d'Egypte pour l'Europe, l'Amérique du Nord et du Sud, l'Afrique orientale, méridionale et occidentale, les Indes, l'Australie, la Nouvelle-Zélande, la Chine et le Japon. Pour assurer une transmission rapide, les télégrammes doivent porter l'indication Via Eastern.

Voir le temps moyen de transmission le plus récent jusqu' Londres au bulletin journalier publié dans ce journal. STATIONS EN EGYPTE Alexandrie, le Caire, Sues, Port-Tewak, Port-Said, Souakin. Bureau principal à Londres

Editor & Manager: R. Snelling.
Price: One Piastre Tariff.
MONDAY, NOVEMBER 14, 1904.

div.head: CAIRO TRAMS.
div.p: More than once it has been a pleasure to us to acknowledge the efficiency of the services of the Cairo Tramway Company and the evident desire of the management to meet the wishes of the public in every possible manner. We have therefore no hesitation in calling the attention of the manager to the irregularity of the service between the Citadel and the Esbekieh that has for some time past been very noticeable. A correspondent who uses this service daily com- plains that of late, sometimes on two or three mornings in succession, he has had to wait ten minutes or more for a car to find, when one did arrive, that it was not only packed full but was garlanded by a picturesque array of passengers clinging to every available stanchion and handle. Such incidents are not perhaps wholly avoidable. Accidents will happen, as the old adage has it, in the best regulated families, but weare afraid that in many instances the cause of these. delays is to be attributed to the want of tact on the part of the police, who when called upon to deal with a refractory passenger, or to act upon the complaint of some one, proceed to treat the affair in a leisurely manner that is not at all justifiable. If, as occurs from time to time, the police find it necessary to make a more or less extended enquiry, or to require the attendance of a passenger, or one of the company's officials serving with the car, it should be sufficient for them to detain the persons necessary and permit the car to proceed. If it be necessary, in the interests of justice or otherwise, to detain the driver or conductor of a car, we see no reason why this should not be done and the place of the man so delayed taken by the corresponding official of the next car to arrive at the spot and making the same journey. In this way all needs would be filled and the sight now to too often seen of a string of four or more cars blocking up the traffic, while a policeman makes a close inquest into some trivial complaint, would not be so common. We cannot but think that if the company would make a suggestion of this kind to the police they would be met in every possible way and the public would profit greatly.

div.head: TO-DAY'S TELEGRAMS.
div.p: THE WAR.
WINTER CAMPAIGN.
PESSIMISM AT MUKDEN.

PARIS, November 13. A telegram received here from Mukden says that pessimism prevails there anent the prospects of a winter campaign. It is believed that the transport supply question will be the most difficult.
RUSSIAN WAR LOAN.
(Reuter.)
PARIS, November 13.

The Echo de Paris learns from St. Peters- burg that a Russian loan of £53,000,000 has been arranged with German and Dutch banks. £45,000,000 will be issued in Germany and the rest at Amsterdam. The greater part of the money is to remain in Germany, and will be used as a guarantee in connection with. orders for numerous warships. (Reuter.)
JAPAN'S FOREIGN LOAN. FINANCE MINISTER NOT SATISFIED.
TOKIO, November 12. The prospectus of the Japanese loan, men- tioned on the 8th inst., has been issued. The loan is repayable in 1911, and secured on the Customs. (Reuter.)

ToxIO, November 12. The Minister for Finance states that the Government is not satisfied with the terms of the foreign loan, but the delay in the capture of Port Arthur and the departure of the Baltic Fleet compelled the acceptance of terms less favourable than the first loan. (Reuter.)
TRANS-SIBERIAN RAILWAY. DOUBLING OF TRACK.
ST. PETERSBURG, November 18.
The Tsar has approved of the scheme for doubling the track of the Trans-Siberian Rail
way.
(Reuter.)
ANGLO-FRENCH AGREEMENT.
PASSED BY CHAMBER.
PARIS, November 12.
The Chamber has approved of M. Delcassé's declaration anent the Anglo-French Agreement
by 438 votes to 94.
(Reuter.)
PARIS, November 12.
The Chamber of Deputies has passed the
Anglo-French Convention.
(Havas.)
PARIS, November 18. The Chamber has ratified the Franco-Sin mese Convention, and also the Anglo-French Convention concerning Newfoundland and West and Central Africa, by 443 votes to 105. (Reuter.)
THE KOWEY DIFFICULTY. LORD LANSDOWNE'S REPLY.
LONDON, November 13.

Lord Lansdowne told the Porte that the Agent is only at Koweyt temporarily in order to settle certain affairs. His lordship, however, cannot deal with the case so long as the Aden" question is not settled. (Reuter.)
AMERICAN NAVY
BIG INCREASE IN PERSONNEL.
WASHINGTON, November 13.
The Government is increasing the personnel of the Navy to 64,445 men, which is more than double the number at present. The increase is in connection with the new building programme
HORSHAM ELECTION.
(Reuter.)
LONDON, November 12.
Lord Tumour, Conservative and Chamber lainite, has been elected by 4,388 votes against Mr. Erskine, Liberal, 8,604.
(Reuter.)

div.head: THE BALTIC FLEET.
div.p: QUESTION OF NEUTRALITY.
DIVERGENCES OF OPINION.
FLEET AT DAKAR.

PARIS, November 12. The Temps states that the Japanese Minister called upon M. Delcassé yesterday with reference to certain points relating to tho observance of neutrality by France. There are grounds for believing that divergences of opinion have arisen. The same, however, must not be over-rated as they will soon be removed, since France has hitherto reconciled her duties as an ally of Russia with those of a neutral Power. Japan, on the other hand, appreciates the uprightness of French intentions in the delicate situation. Explanations are proceeding amicably.
The above doubtless refers to coaling and other naval facilities which have been given to the Russians by French colonies. (Reuter.)
PARIS, November 13.
It is stated that Japan has called the atten- tion of the governments to the maintenance of a striet neutrality with regard to the passage of the Russian Baltic Squadron. (Havas.)
DAKAR, November 13.
Four Russian battleships, 5 cruisers and 7
transports have arrived here.
(Reuter.)
DAKAR, November 12.
(Havas.)
The Russian Fleet has arrived.
FRENCH SENATE.
PARIS, November 13.
M. Wallon, Senator, is dead.
M. Destournelles has been elected Senator.
SYVETON-DUGAIL DUEL.
(Havas.)
PARIS, November 12.
The duel between M. Syveton and Captain
Daguail has taken place. Two shots were
exchanged without result.(Havas.)
OBITUARY.
London, November 12.
Mr. Valentine Prinsep, the artist, and Mr. George Lennox Watson, the yacht designer, are dead.
(Reuter.)
LOCAL AND GENERAL.
TRANSPORT OF CATTLE-The Ministry of the Interior has issued instructions to all Governors and Moudirs on the subject of the transport of cattle.
ZIZINIA THEATRE.-M. Silvain, the celebrat- ed French tragedian, opens a short season at this theatre this evening with Victor Hugo's Le Roi s'amuse.
A COMPETITOR TO EGYPT.-It is announced that the people of Sindh are this year export ing three hundred thousand bales of improved cotton equal to Egyptian.
FRENCH SCHOOL OF LAW.-The beginning of the course for the three years licentiate at the French School of Law at Cairo is fixed for Thursday next, 17th inst., at 3.30 p.m.
MEDICAL LICENSES.-Drs. J. S. Bordach and Emin Malouf have been authorised by the Ministry of the Interior to practise in Egypt. M. Franz Moldehuke has been authorised to practise as a pharmacist.

BRITISH SOLDIER DROWNED. On Saturday afternoon the corpse of Private Sinclair, of the 2nd Battalion Royal Inniskilling Fusiliers, was found in the Nile at Ghizeh. The funeral took place yesterday afternoon.
NEWSPAPER LIBEL CASE-Mr. Gammal, a wealthy Alexandrian, has brought an action for libel against the proprietor and editor of the Tamiel, a local Arabic newspaper. £1000 damages are claimed.

THE ANNIVERSARY of the death of Ismail Pasha was commemorated yesterday evening at the Daira of Kasr el-Aly by a religious cere- mony. Some verses of the Koran were read and'alms were given to the poor at the ceme- tery of the Khedivial family.
Of these, 10 The transit

SUEZ CANAL. On the 10th inst. 11 vessels passed through the Suez Canal. were British and 1 was Prench. and passenger dues for the day amounted to 314,821.49 frs. The total transit and passenger dues collected from the 1st inst. to that date on 120 vessels amounted to 3,174,893.54 frs.

MR. JOHN B. CAPPARI wishes to inform his clients that, owing to the expiration of the lease of his old premises in the Grand Square his offices and stores have been removed to 8, Rue de l'Eglise Debbane and 6, Boulevard de Ramleh. As the fittings of the offices, shop, and stores are not yet completed, some of the back stores will be used temporarily, with entrance from 8, Rue de l'Eglise Debbane.

note.p: THE HORSHAM ELECTION results, asgiven in this morning's telegrams, are cold comfort for the Ante-Chamberlainites. The late member, Mr. Heywood Johnstone, was so well known and so popular in the constituency, which he had represented since 1893, that it was diffi cult for a new candidate to fill his place in the favours of that division of the county, but Lord Turnour has romped in with nearly 800 votes to the good.

A NEW HOSPITAL will shortly very probably be erected in Old Cairo by the Church Mis- sionary Society. It will be an extension of the Society's present hospital and will be construct- ed specially for the use of women and children. It is to be erected in memory of the wife of Dr. Maynard Pain, of the C.M.S. in Old Cairo. That lady, it will be remembered, died in Cairo a year ago. It is estimated that nearly £2,400 will be required and of this sum nearly £1,900 has already been subscribed.
THE KHEDIVE.
The Khedive held an "Iftar" on Saturday evening at Abdeen Palace, which was attended by a large number of retired high officials.

His Highness received Commodore Coun douriotis, the Admiral of the Greek Fleet, and his commanding officers this morning at Abdeen Palace. They were presented to the Khedive by M. Gennadis, Hellenic Diplomatic Agent and Consul-General at Cairo.

MENA HOUSE COACH UPSET. An accident that might have been very serious happened to the Mena House coach yesterday morning, about half-a-mile from the bridge. One of the horses-a magnificent team recently imported from Hungary-became restive and swerved to the left close to the trees, against one of which the coach collided.. Owing to the impact the entire coach turned turtle and the four passengers, driver, and groom were thrown to the ground. The driver pluckily stuck to his reins and did his utmost to avert disaster, and owing to his own cool- ness was thrown rather heavily in front of the coach. He was unconscious for a few minutes but was at once rescued from the horse by the passengers, who had by this time alighted. The groom crushed his foot and was taken to the German Hospital and is little the worse beyond a fow contusions.

A subscription of 10 shillings was collected among the passengers and presented to the driver by Mr. Norman Hamilton, who was on the box-seat at the time of the accident, and who addressed a few complimentary remarks to the driver, a brave Italian, who deserved the utmost credit for his conduct and to whom not the slightest blame attached.
HELOUAN.

The Grand Hotel Helouan is daily receiving new arrivals. We notice among the visitors at this hotel Mr. A. Byddulph Myddelton, Mr. and Mrs. Pettigrew, from London, Mr. Schwe- rin, M. A. Rossano, Mr. S. A. Fisher and Dr. Campbell Ward, from Harrogate, Mr. Sidney Halifax, Mr. Wright Henderson, M. F. Suares, from Cairo, Mr. Ed. Downham, from Poole, Mr. J. Bibby, froin Birkenhead, Mr. Bretschneider, Mrs. and the Misses Gollock, from London.

Many applications for rooms have been received lately. Among the visitors shortly expected are: Col. and Mrs. Spearman, Mrs. Birley, Mr. Fildes, Mr. and Mrs. Jebb Scott, Capt. and Mrs. W. Leetham, Mr. and Mrs. Th. Jimmins and party, Miss James and party. The golf professional, who has been specially engaged by the manager of the Grand Hotel, is expected in a few days, and the links is now open for the use of visitors staying either at the Grand Hotel or at the Hotel des Bains.

The Bath Establishment of Helouan, under the management of the George Nungovich Hotels Company, has been entirely renewed during the last summer. Three more of the famous so-called Helouan baths (bath with massage under water) have been added during the summer. From now and during the whole season eight European experienced masseurs and masseuses from Aix-les-Bains and Harrogate, will be in attendance. A new Vichy bath will also be installed at the Bath Establishment, which may be visited at any time of the day.
LETTER TO THE EDITOR. REDUCTION OF GARRISON.

TO THE EDITOR OF THE EGYPTIAN GAZETTE. Dear Sir, Some time ago I sent you a very characteristic comment of the Duke of Wel- lington on the reductions in the Indian army which precipitated the Sikh war. I trust you will find space in your columns for a selection from the second volume of Lord Dalhousie's Life, which explains readily why the great event of 1857 was so very nearly successful. In 1854 Lord Dalhousie wrote to Sir Charles Wood:-

"I cannot believe that the Queen's Government would diminish the compara- tively small European force in India without any reference to the Government of the country. I wish to say to you emphatically that two European regiments cannot be safely withdrawn, especially now. Our Raj is safe from risk, but only while we are strong. We positively must not be weaken- ed. I adjure you not to allow us to be weakened in European infantry."

In a subsequent minute he recorded:-"The Government of India has no element of national strength on which it can fall back in a country where the entire English community is but a handful of scattered strangers."
History has an unfortunate habit of repeating itself, and I put this quotation before those of my countrymen in whose eyes two and two make four and not two two's.
Yours truly,
DISQUIETED.
Cairo, November 12,
GREEK FLEET'S VISIT.
AN UNFORTUNATE CONTRETEMPS.
SAILOR DROWNED.

At eleven o'clock on Saturday morning, while the train containing 750 sailors and petty officers from all the ships of the Greek squadron was on the bridge of the Mahmou- dieh Canal, going to the Antoniades Garden, one of the sailors of the Hydra, by name Spindor Milionis, got out of the train and fell through one of the spaces in t the bridege, near Hadra station, and after being severely stun- ned, fell into the canal, where he was ultimately drowned. The body of the unfortunate man was not found until 6 o'clock in the evening and was then taken to the Greek Hospital for identification, etc. The body remained there all night.
THE FUNERAL.

At 3 o'clock yesterday afternoon, a small detachment from the ship Hydra, accompanied by the band of the vessel, escorted the body of the deceased sailor, which was placed on a gun carriage, to the Greek cemetery, followed by a vast concourse of people. The burial service was read by the local Bishop, at the chapel of the Greek-Orthodox cemetery. The body was then deposited in the grave and three volleys were fired by the escort. There were three big wreaths, one from the crew of the Hydra, one from the Hellenic community, and one from Mr. Anthony Benachi. The chief mourner was represented by Mr. Scotides, the Consul-General. Besides all the officers of the ship wo remarked Mr. Michel Sinadino, the personnel of the Greek Consulate, the Greek Judge, Mr. G. Zervudachi, Dr. Valasopoulo, Mr. M. S. Salvago, Mr. N. Sinadino. Mr. Ant. and Alex. Benachi, Mr. Paraskevas, Mr. E. Minotto, the personnel of the Greek Hospital, and many others. The crowd at the cemetery and along the roads outside may be estimated at about, 10,000 people. After the conclusion of the ceremony, the escort marched back to the ship, headed by the band playing a march, and accompanied by a large crowd of people.
SATURDAY'S PICNIC.

In spite of the death of the sailor Milionis, which threatened to postpone the proceedings, the picnic given in honour of the petty officers and sailors of the fleet came off at 12 o'clock on Saturday. Over 750 men sat down to lunch, which was provided by Messrs. Walker and Meimarachi, Ltd., of Alexandria, at the Anto- niades Garden, on the Mahmoudieh Canal. At another table all the leading members of the Hellenic community lunched, amidst the strains of the band of the Greek Philharmonic. Society. In the afternoon all the ladies of the
Hellenic colony here appeared, and the men danced the Greek national dances. The pro- ceedings terminated at 4 o'clock with the singing of the Greek National Anthem.

At 7.30 on Saturday evening H.E. Mahmoud Pasha Sidky, Governor of Alexandria, gave a dinner in honour of the Commodore of the Grook Fleat at the Khedivial Club of Alex andria. His Excellency, who was accompanied by his private secretary, had on his right M. Sootides, the Hellenic Consul-General at Alex- andria, on his left Commodore Coundouriotis, and opposite M. Gennadis, the Greek Diplom- atic Agent in Cairo, on whose right was Cap- tain Ghinis, of the flag-ship Psara, and on his left Captain Damianos, of the Hydra.

Among the others invited were Mr. E. Bena- chi, the president of the Hellenic community, Mr. M. Sinadino, Colonel Hopkinson Bey, the Greek judges, Messrs. Pangalo, Dimaras, Anto- niadis, and Papadopoulo, Mr. M. Salvago, Mr. Amb. Ralli, Mr. N. Tamvaco, Mr. G. Zervuda- chi, and Mr. Ch. Simopoulo.
His Excellency proposed the health of his Majesty the King of Greece and the proceed- ing then terminated.
The party subsequently repaired to the Abbas Helmy Theatre, where a representation of Il Trovatore was given.
DEPARTURE FOR CAIRO.

On Sunday at midday the Greek Commodore D. Coundouriotis, with his staff, five officers from each ship, the head officer of the Com- missariat department, the chief doctor, the head engineer, and the chaplain left for Cairo, accompanied by M. Gennadis, the Greek Diplomatic Agent at Cairo, by whom they were presented to his Highness the Khedive. By the same train Mr. E. Bonachi, president of the Greek community, also left. They are patting up at the Continental Hotel, where rooms had been reserved for them. We understand that the programme to be followed in Cairo is the following:

Monday. Presentation to H.H. the Khedive. Then a Te Deum at the Greek-Orthodox Church St. Nicola, and at night a dinner at the Continental Hotel, given in honour of the officers by the Greek colony at Cairo. Tuesday. Picnic to the Barrage.
Wednesday. Excursion to the Pyramids, where tea will be given, and a "Punch" at the Greek Club given to the officers by the Hellenic colony of Cairo.
On Thursday they return to Alexandria.

New York dogs are now fitted out with on armoured coat staddol with sharp steel spikes, to enab e them to play "teuch las" on the public highway without that risk of getting squashed by a motor car which so annoys the high-spirited dog. If the armourd dog is run into by a car. his spikes puncture the tyre and the rush of released air blows him out of dange
GRAND HOTEL BONNARD,
ALEXANDRIA.
8s. PER DAY, WINE INCLUDED,
THE CATTLE PLAGUE.
NEW REGULATIONS
The following arrêté has been issued by th Ministry of the Interior:-
Art. 1. Without the previous authorisation of the authorities designed by the Sanitary Administration and conformity with th provisions of the said authorisation,
(a.) The transport of cattle or buffaloe from one village to another, and, (b) The trade in and transport of driec hides and bones of cattle, are forbidden. Art. 2. It is strictly prohibited
(a.) To engage in the trade in or transpor of raw hides;
(b) To slaughter any cattle or buffaloe outside the public abattoirs in localities declared infected by cattle plague;
(c). To transport from one village to anothe the flesh of cattle unless they have been slaughtered in such abattoirs.

3. The decree of June 14, 1904, is horeby abrogated and replaced by the present decreem 4. The present decree shall come into force at once and romain in force for 6 months unless previously abrogated.
THE LATE TIGRANE PASHA.

The body of Tigrane Pasha arrives at Alex andria this afternoon by the North German Lloyd 8.8. Schleswig. The Sub-Governor o Alexandria and a detachment of police will proceed to the quays to receive the body which is to be despatched this afternoon te Cairo by a special train direct from the quay.
THE NEW STEAMSHIP LINE

The arrival of the S.S. Schleswig at Alexan dria this afternoon inaugurates the new Medi terranean service of the North German Lloyd. The Schleswig left Marseilles on Wednesday and Naples at noon on Friday. She had 23 passengers on board, of whom 135 were first and 59 second class. Among the passengers were Prince Aslan d'Abro Pagradite, Mr. and Mrs Charles Bayerlé, Mme. Bustros, Prince and Princess Hussein, Izzet Pasha and Princese Faika Izzet, Baron and Baronne Menasce Tueni Bey, Mr. Michael Sursock, Comte and Comtesse de Serionne, Mme. C. Salvago Boghos Pasha Nubar, and Mrs. G. B. Alderson
NEW ARCHEOLOGICAL SOCIETY.

A new society has been successfully started in Paris under most distinguished auspices, in imitation of the Egypt, Palestine, and Cretan Exploration Funds. It is entitled "La Société Française de Fouilles Archéolo- giques." The first grant of funds will almost certainly be apportioned to M. Gayet to

assist him in further excavations at Antinoe.. As evidence of the "entente cordiale," the committee are desirous of having British mem- bers, and our correspondent Mr. Offord is the first such elected. The president is M. Babelon of the "Cabinet des Medailles." The annual subscription, which entitles members to the publications, is 20 francs.
ABBAS HELMY THEATRE.

This theatre was again crowded on Saturday evening, when Verdi's Il Trovatore was pro- duced, and it was evident from the rounds of applause bestowed on the artistes throughout the evening that the performance fully reached their expectations, and was indeed an unqual ified success. Signora Fabbri's Azucena was an interpretation of that difficult role the like of which, both from a musical and histrionic point of view, it has seldom been our pleasure to hear. As Leonora Signora Popovici scored another distinct success. She sang and acted with that grace and skill which always cha racterize her performanoes, and with Signora Fabbri, shared in the enthusiastic plandits so lavishly bestowed and so richly deserv ed. Both these ladies were presented with handsome bouquets. Signor Venerandi was a very acceptable Manrico and met with hearty applauso. The famous aria at the end of the third act he was compelled to- repeat no less than thrice. The whole of the artistes were recalled continually.

A word of praise is again due to the chorus for the excellent manner in which their work is performed, the hidden choruses being parti cularly pleasing. It is hardly necessary to say that the orchestra, under the able baton of Sig. Falooni, was, as it always is, perfection..

The performance was under the distinguish- ed patronage and presence of H.B. the Go- vernor of Alexandria, who occupied the Khe dive's box, accompanied by the Commodore and officers of the Greek Squadron. A large number of Greek naval officers and many local hotables were also present in other parts of the house.
This evening there will be no performance, To-morrow Andrea Chenier will be given, with Signa. Popovici in the caste.
Yesterday's Italian mailboat brought the celebrated singer Signa. Monti-Baldini and the tenor Alfredo Torniani, who will shortly make their appearance in Carmen and Mignon.
YACHTING.

The British turbine yacht Emerald, which is bound for a oruise to the China Seas, left Alexandria harbour yesterday evening. The French yacht Fiorentina II. also sailed yesterday evening bound in the same direction
as the Emerald.
WINDSOR HOTEL.
Largest 1st class and most comfortable Hotel in Alexandria. Facing the sea Central position. Under English management. 91-11-904
COQUELIN AINE AT CAIRO.
"TARTUPB"

We had Tartufe, followed by Les Precieuses Ridicules on Thursday night, and the: Open House was, quite naturally, full and the audience as enthusiastia as it could be Co quelin's Tartufe was of course the perform ance that dwarfed everything else. His com mand and control of facial expression were equally amazing. He never underlined, and to the British theatre-goer, who is accustomed to over-aeting, that fact alone was almost-as astonishing as his historie sense. Tartufe is no modern imposter as loquacious as be is underbred, all things to all men and more shamelessly fluent than his prospeotas. He is the typical imposter of a dignified epoch-when- the lowest villains had a grand air and when honest people were not compelled to career through life, at high pressure under pain of being outstripped by their friends, and.com sequently had time to look around them and, among other interesting subjects, to stady character. We do not say they studied it consciously or as a science, but having produe. ed a very distinct and general type of educated man, who differed as greatly from the man of the fifteenth century as he differs from the man of the nineteenth, they insisted on,the neces dity incumbent on all decent persons to be tamped with part at least of the pattern of a peial trademark. Nowadays we would not He duped by Tartufo, who would be uni versally cut as a sanctimonious boro or as

consistent eccentride Yet, we seem to remember cases in country towns where ditions who were distinguished as "worthy' or Christian men and had even become churchwardens, ended their days in gaol or were last heard of in South American republics.
Of the other actors, Mlle Suzanne Devoyod mada a very charming Elvire; but Mlle Boa chetal was not very distinct and M. Chabert Damis) overacted.

After the performance of Tartufe came Les Précieuses Hidicules and a great improvement in the other members of the company, who had ot been able to save the Alexandrines of Tartufe from monotony only relieved by Co- quelin's splendid enunciation and delivery of the long lines. Mllo Devoyod was again good Magdalen, but rather failed to bring out the humour of her part, and Mlle Bouchatal as Cathos greatly improved on her Doringre. M. Rosenberg, who had made Orgon too much, in our opinion, of a buffoon in Tartufe, repeated the Orgonic gestures as Gorgibus. Coquetin's rendering of Mascarille's song deserved even more than the applause it received.
"L'ABBE CONSTANTIN."

On Friday night L'Abbé Constantin made a welcome reappearance in Cairo, and was well received.by an appreciative house. The piece is merely a parlour play, and albeit light and trifling, rivets the attention of the spectator by its amusing situations and dialogue. M. Coquelin again showed himself a master of the quiet method of acting, as opposed to the Borid style that involves so much violent gesticulation and rushing about the stage;
trusting to his inimitable variety of a

trusting to his inimitable variety of expression, he assumed now a look of bland innooonce, now a twinkle of arch cynicism, followed by a most suave and affable smile to his friends and guests, while his unique powers of artion- lation made even his whispers andible all over the house. We liked him best in the third act, though in the first his dinner and siosta wore most amusingly rendered. It is a pity that the mise-en-scene and the characters call for so little comment, with the exception perhaps of Mmo. Suzanne Devoyod and some spirited acting by M. Rosenberg, which met with the appreciation it deserved.
"CYRANO DE BERGERAC."

Le cour a ses raisons, which opened: Satur- day night's performance, is an amusing little curtain-raiser, slight, witty, and well-perform- ed, but we would have given anything to hear another act of Cyrano de Bergerac. We had the 3rd and 5th acts with Coquelin at his best. The staging of the balcony scene was hopeless ly bad, but the fact that the night, on which all depends, was thoroughly illuminated, hade no difference whatever to the quality of his performance. Many first-rate actors would have faltered before the unreality of the mise-en- scène, but Coquelin carried through magnifi cently what is probably his finest performance. If you doubt it foad Cyrano and try to imagine. the possibility of such a man in real life. Yet Coquelin makes him not only possible but eminently probable and convincing.
STEAMER MOVEMENTS.
The Messageries Maritimes 8.8. Portugal, which left Marseilles on Thursday, passed through the Straits of Messina on Saturday and is due here to-morrow morning.
The Ellerman 8.8. Athenian arrived here on Friday afternoon from Liverpool, and Gibraltar with mails and general cargo.

& HOTEL COMPANY.

NOTES FROM TANTAH.
TELEGRAPH ADMINISTRATION.
Tantah, Sunday.

I am glad to place on record that, after my repeated complaints, the Telegraph Adminis tration has at last taken steps to improve the service here. A supplementary line is now working with Alexandria, and the result is that telegrams are transmitted quickly (6 mifiatér for ordinary telegrams in some cases). Im congratulate the Telegraph Department on having met the claims of the public.
GREEK VICE-CONSUL
Mr. Nicolas Golemas, Greek Vice-Conaal in Tantab, has been replaced by an official from the Alexandria Consulate. There are remours that he will not return here.
THE TANZIM.

The Tanzim Department here, as elsewhere in Egypt, seems to have been created against the interests of the town: Now that the electrio light has been installed, all the old lainpe, etc. have had to be put away, and as the Tammine people had no room in the stores they have simply barrioaded the side street near the tores at both ends and now use this as stone is
PERSONAL AND SOCIAL
The King of Italy has bestowed on the Governor of Alexandria the 3rd class (cod- mander) of the Order of the Italian Crown.

The death is announced of the Arohiman- drite Germanos, who for some years past has represented the Patriarch of Alexandria at the Ecumenical Patriarchate. The Arobimandrite died suddenly on Friday wook at the residence of Mgr. Mihall, Metropolitan of Sardes and Director of the National School at Phanary with whom he had been staying since the previous Wednesday.

The funeral of Miss Mary Barsook, the daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Alexander Sureeck will take place to-morrow. The cortage will leave the residence of the deceased's parents at 72, Rosetta-avenue, at 3.30 p.m.
Dr. Allingham, whose reputation as a surgical operator was world-wide, while on his way hat week to Egypt, where he intended to make long stay for the benefit of his health, died at Marseilles.
Professor Schweinfurth leaves Berlin to-day for Egypt.
Mr. and Mrs. A. J. Michaelidos have left for Heloaan, to spend the winter season.
PASSENGER LISTS.
ARRIVALS

DEPARTURES..
Le paquebot Cleopatra, du Lloyd Autrichien parti samedi pour Trieste avait à bord:

Clelia Perera, C. J. Wade, ing: Silvio Bassi et sa dame, C. Baushaf, W. Leo, Mack, Cap. Oxley, Comtesse d'Arfouille, Mile d'Arfeuille, Mime Buehler, M. et Mme Brownsen, Kross okackner, Ch. Rud. Franke, Léon Oroedi, G Hacker, G. MetHoovita, sosur Cristina Kalkahl, G. Bondermann; Hoffer, L. Avram, B. M. Con gliano et 28 passagers de me classe,
